DOC.HEAD: Hearing Begins on Manslaughter Charges in Ferry Disaster
DOC.TEXT: A hearing began Monday on whether there is enough evidence to try P and O European Ferries and seven company executives and seamen for manslaughter in the Zeebrugge ferry disaster, which killed 193 people. P and O is charged with corporate manslaughter, the first such prosecution in England, because of the accident in 1987. The ferry Herald of Free Enterprise was swamped when its rear doors were left open, and capsized outside the harbor of Zeebrugge, Belgium. The hearing is expected to last about three weeks. The decision to presecute capped more than two years of court and police proceedings, a public inquiry that blamed the ship owners and an inquest that returned a verdict of unlawful killing. If tried and found guilty, the company could be liable to an unlimited fine and the individuals could face maximum sentences of life in prison. No pleas were taken Monday. Appearing in court were John Alcindor, deputy chief superintendent of P and O European Ferries; Wallace Ayres, director and head of its technical department; Jeffrey Develin, director and chief (marine) superintendent; Capt. David Lewry, captain of the ferry; and senior master John Kirby. Two other men, first officer Leslie Sabel and assistant bosun Mark Stanley, decided not to participate in the first phase of the preliminary hearing, but were to appear when the evidence has been completed in the cases of the other men. Summonses against the company and individual defendants accuse them of the manslaughter of four victims: passengers Alison Gaillard and Martin Spooner, and crew members Richard Barnard and Maria Richards. The father of Mrs. Gaillard, who died with her husband Francis, is Maurice de Rohan, chairman of the Herald Families Association. Spooner's father, Peter, is the association secretary.
